column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.3
#T_SP=custom.Span|label
#T_RL=custom.Relation|label|BT_custom.Span
#Text=It seems highly probable that, as has been especially emphasized by Hagen, perfumes were primitively used by women,
#Text=not as is sometimes the case in civilization, with the idea of
#Text=disguising any possible natural odor, but with the object of
#Text=heightening and fortifying the natural odor.
#Text=If the primitive
#Text=man was inclined to disparage a woman whose odor was slight
#Text=or imperceptible, — turning away from her with contempt, as
#Text=the Polynesian turned away from the ladies of Sydney : "They
#Text=have no smell!"
#Text=— women would inevitably seek to supplement
#Text=any natural defects in this respect, and to accentuate their
#Text=odorous qualities, in the same way as by corsets and bustles,
#Text=even in civilization, they have sought to accentuate the sexual
#Text=saliencies of their bodies.
#Text=In this way we may, as Hagen suggests, explain the fact that until recent times the odors preferred
#Text=by women have not been the most delicate or exquisite, but the
#Text=strongest, the most animal, the most sexual : musk, castoreum,
#Text=civet, and ambergris.
#Text=In that interesting novel — dealing with the adventures of a Jewish
#Text=maiden at the Persian court of Xerxes — which under the title of
#Text=Esther has found its way into the Old Testament we are told that it
#Text=was customary in the royal harem at Shushan to submit the women to
#Text=a very prolonged course of perfuming before they were admitted
#Text=to the king: "six months with oil of myrrh and six months with
#Text=sweet odors."
#Text={Esther, Chapter II, v. 12.)
#Text=In the Arabian Nights there are many allusions to the use of perfumes by women with a more or less definitely stated aphrodisiacal
#Text=intent.
#Text=Thus we read in the story of Kamaralzaman: "With fine incense I will perfume my breasts, my belly, my whole body, so that my
#Text=skin may melt more sweetly in thy mouth, O apple of my eye!"
#Text=Even among savages the perfuming of the body is sometimes practiced with the object of inducing love in the partner.
#Text=Schellong states
#Text=that the Papuans of Kaiser Wilhelm's Land rub various fragrant plants
#Text=into their bodies for this purpose.
#Text={Zeitschrift fur Ethnologic, 1899, ht.
#Text=i, p. 19.)
#Text=The significance of this practice is more fully revealed by Haddon when studying the Papuans of Torres Straits, among whom the
#Text=initiative in courtship is taken by the women.
#Text=It was by scenting
#Text=himself with a pungent odorous substance that a young man indicated
#Text=that he was ready to be sued by the girls.
#Text=A man would wear this
#Text=scent at the back of his neck during a dance in order to attract the

#Text=attention of a particular girl; it was believed to act with magical certainty, after the manner of a charm (Reports of the Cambridge Anthropological Expedition to Torres Straits, vol. v, pp. 211, 222, and 328).
#Text=The perfume which is of all perfumes the most interesting
#Text=from the present point of view is certainly musk.
#Text=With ambergris, musk is the chief member of Linnseus ' s group of Odores
#Text=ambrosiacce, a group which in sexual significances, as Zwaardemaker remarks, ranks besides the capryl group of odors.
#Text=It
#Text=is a perfume of ancient origin ; its name is Persian 1 (indicating
#Text=doubtless the channel whence it reached Europe) and ultimately derived from the Sanskrit word for testicle in allusion
#Text=to the fact that it was contained in a pouch removed from the
#Text=sexual parts of the male musk-deer.
#Text=Musk odors, however,
#Text=often of considerable strength, are very widely distributed in
#Text=Nature, alike among animals and plants.
#Text=This is indicated
#Text=by the frequency with which the word "musk" forms part of
#Text=the names of animals and plants which are by no means always nearly related.
#Text=We have the musk-ox, the musky mole,
#Text=several species called musk-rat, the musk-duck, the muskbeetle; while among plants which have received their names
#Text=from a real or supposed musky odor are, besides several that
#Text=are called musk-plant, the musk-rose, the musk-hyacinth, the
#Text=musk-mallow, the musk-orchid, the musk-melon, the muskcherry, the musk-pear, the musk-plum, muskat and muscatels,
#Text=musk-seed, musk-tree, musk-wood, etc. 2 But a musky odor
#Text=is not merely widespread in Nature among plants and the
#Text=lower animals, it is peculiarly associated with man.
#Text=Incidentally we have already seen how it is regarded as characteristic of some races of man, especially the Chinese.
#Text=Moreover,
#Text=the smell of the negress is said to be musky in character, and
#Text=
#Text=
#Text=among Europeans a musky odor is said to be characteristic of
#Text=blondes.
#Text=Laycock, in his Nervous Diseases of Women, stated
#Text=his opinion that "the musk odor is certainly the sexual odor
#Text=of man"; and Fere states that the musk odor is that among
#Text=natural perfumes most nearly approaching the odor of the sexual secretions.
#Text=We have seen that the Chinese poet vaunts
#Text=the musky odor of his mistress ' s armpits, while another Oriental saying concerning the attractive woman is that "her navel
#Text=is filled with musk."
#Text=Persian literature contains many references to musk as an attractive body odor, and Firdusi speaks
#Text=of a woman ' s hair as "a crown of musk," while the Arabian
#Text=poet Motannabi says of his mistress that "her hyacinthine hair
#Text=smells sweeter than Scythian musk."
#Text=Galopin stated that he
#Text=knew women whose natural odor of musk (and less frequently
#Text=of ambergris) was sufficiently strong to impart to a bath in
#Text=less than an hour a perfume due entirely to the exhalations
#Text=of the musky body; it must be added that Galopin was an enthusiast in this matter.
#Text=The special significance of musk from our present point
#Text=of view lies not only in the fact that we here have a perfume,
#Text=widely scattered throughout nature and often in an agreeable
#Text=form, which is at the same time a very frequent personal odor
#Text=in man.
#Text=Musk is the odor which not only in the animals to
#Text=which it has given a name, but in many others, is a specifically
#Text=sexual odor, chiefly emitted during the sexual season.
#Text=The sexual odors, indeed, of most animals seem to be modifications of
#Text=musk.
#Text=The Sphinx moth has a musky odor which is confined
#Text=to the male and is doubtless sexual.
#Text=Some lizards have a musky
#Text=odor which is heightened at the sexual season; crocodiles during the pairing season emit from their submaxillary glands a
#Text=musky odor which pervades their haunts.
#Text=In the same way
#Text=elephants emit a musky odor from their facial glands during
#Text=the rutting season.
#Text=The odor of the musk-duck is chiefly confined to the breeding season. 1 The musky odor of the negress
#Text=is said to be heightened during sexual excitement.
#Text=The predominance of musk as a sexual odor is associated
#Text=with the fact that its actual nervous influence, apart from the
#Text=presence of sexual associations, is very considerable.
#Text=Fere
#Text=found it to be a powerful muscular stimulant.
#Text=In former times
#Text=musk enjoyed a high reputation as a cardiac stimulant; it fell
#Text=into disuse, but in recent years its use in asthenic states has
#Text=been revived, and excellent results, it has been claimed, have
#Text=followed its administration in cases of collapse from Asiatic
#Text=cholera.
#Text=For sexual torpor in women it still has (like vanilla
#Text=and sandal) a certain degree of reputation, though it is not
#Text=often used, and some of the old Arabian physicians (especially
#Text=Avicenna) recommended it, with castoreum and myrrh, for
#Text=amenorrhoea.
#Text=Its powerful action is indicated by the experience of Esquirol, who stated that he had seen cases in which
#Text=sensory stimulation by musk in women during lactation had
#Text=produced mania.
#Text=It has always had the reputation, more especially in the Mohammedan East, of being a sexual stimulant
#Text=to men ; "the noblest of perfumes/ '  it is called in El Ktab, "and
#Text=that which most provokes to venery."

column3:
_	_	_	

#Text=Not only is musk the most cherished perfume of the
#Text=Islamic world, and the special favorite of the Prophet himself,
#Text=who greatly delighted in perfumes (I love your world," he is

column1: #Text=reported to have said in old age, "for its women and its perfumes"), 1 it is the only perfume generally used by the women of
#Text=a land in which the refinements of life have been carried so
#Text=far as Japan, and they received it from the Chinese. 2
#Text=
#Text=Moreover, musk is still the most popular of European
#Text=perfumes.
#Text=It is the perfumes containing musk, Piesse states in
#Text=his well-known book on the Art of Perfumery, which sell best.
#Text=It is certainly true that in its simple form the odor of musk
#Text=is not nowadays highly considered in Europe.
#Text=This fact is
#Text=connected with the ever-growing refinement in accordance with
#Text=which the specific odors of the sexual regions in human beings
#Text=tend to lose their primitive attractiveness and bodily odors generally become mingled with artificial perfumes and so disguised.
#Text=But, although musk in its simple form, and under its ancient
#Text=name, has lost its hold in Europe, it is an interesting and significant fact that it is still the perfumes which contains musk
#Text=that are the most widely popular.
#Text=Peau d ' Espagne may be mentioned as a highly complex and
#Text=luxurious perfume, often the favorite scent of sensuous persons, which really owes a large part of its potency to the presence of the crude animal sexual odors of musk and civet.
#Text=It
#Text=consists of wash-leather steeped in ottos of neroli, rose, santal,
#Text=lavender, verbena, bergamot, cloves, and cinnamon, subsequently smeared with civet and musk.
#Text=It is said by some, probably with a certain degree of truth, that Peau d ' Espagne is of
#Text=
#Text=all perfumes that which most nearly approaches the odor of a
#Text=woman ' s skin; whether it also suggests the odor of leather is
#Text=not so clear.
#Text=There is, however, no doubt that the smell of leather has
#Text=a curiously stimulating sexual influence on many men and
#Text=women.
#Text=It is an odor which seems to occupy an intermediate
#Text=place between the natural body odors and the artificial perfumes for which it sometimes serves as a basis; possibly it is
#Text=to this fact that its occasional sexual influence is owing, for, as
#Text=Ave have already seen, there is a tendency for sexual allurement
#Text=to attach to odors which are not the specific personal body odors
#Text=but yet are related to them.
#Text=Moll considers, no doubt rightly,
#Text=that shoe fetichism, perhaps the most frequent of sexual fetichistic perversions, is greatly favored, if, indeed, it does not owe
#Text=its origin to, the associated odor of the feet and of the shoes.
#Text=He narrates a case of shoe fetichism in a man in which the perversion began at the age of 6, when for the first time he wore
#Text=new shoes, having previously used only the left-off shoes of his
#Text=elder brother; he felt and smelt these new shoes with sensations of unmeasured pleasure; and a few years later began to
#Text=use shoes as a method of masturbation.
#Text=ISTacke has also recorded the case of a shoe fetichist who declared that the sexual
#Text=attraction of shoes (usually his wife ' s) lay largely in the odor
#Text=of the leather.
#Text=Krafft-Ebing, again, brings forward a case
#Text=of shoe fetichism in which the significant fact is mentioned
#Text=that the subject bought a pair of leather cuffs to smell while
#Text=masturbating.
#Text=Eestif de la Bretonne, who was somewhat of a
#Text=shoe fetichist, appears to have enjoyed smelling shoes.
#Text=It is
#Text=not probable that the odor of leather explains the whole of
#Text=shoe fetichism, — as we shall see when, in another "Study," this
#Text=question comes before us — and in many cases it cannot be said
#Text=to enter at all; it is, however, one of the factors.
#Text=Such a conclusion is further supported by the fact that by many the odor
#Text=of new shoes is sometimes desired as an adjuvant to coitus.
#Text=It
#Text=is in the experience of prostitutes that such a device is not in-
#Text=frequent.
#Text=Niieke mentions that a colleague of his was informed
#Text=by a prostitute that several of her clients desired the odor of
#Text=new shoes in the room, and that she was accustomed to obtain
#Text=the desired perfume by holding her shoes for a moment over the
#Text=flame of a spirit lamp.
